#Text=Robert
#Text=Richardson ( Lord Treasurer )
#Text=Robert Richardson
#Text=( died 1578 ) was a Scottish Prior of St Mary 's Isle and royal administrator .
#Text=Biography
#Text=He was the son of Robert Richardson , burgess of Jedburgh ( died ca .

#Text=His great grandfather arrived in Scotland in 1424 in the reign of James I. The historian George Crawfurd asserts that he was descended of a stock of ancient and opulent burgesses of Edinburgh , [ 1 ] but there is little to connect him with the city before 1553 , when he was made a burgess at the request of the fourth earl of Huntly .
#Text=He matriculated at St Salvator 's College , St Andrews , in 1531 , and graduated MA in 1532 .

#Text=Nothing is known of his early career except that in April 1544 he was involved with the Earl of Lennox in armed opposition to the Regent Arran at the battle of Glasgow , for which he later received remission .
#Text=He was presented to the vicarage of Dunsyre in 1549 and held the vicarage of Eckford by 1552 .
#Text=In that year he was provided by the Pope to the archdeaconry of Teviotdale , which he held until 1565 along with the appropriated parsonage of Morebattle .
#Text=In 1558 he obtained crown presentation to the priory of St Mary 's Isle , near Kirkcudbright , which he also resigned in 1565 , retaining the usufruct .
#Text=Richardson 's career as a royal official began around 1549 when he was comptroller clerk .
#Text=In November 1552 he was an auditor of the treasurer 's account .
#Text=Gilbert Kennedy , 3rd Earl of Cassilis
#Text=, appointed lord treasurer in April 1554 , delegated the entire conduct of business to Richardson as treasurer clerk .
#Text=After Cassillis 's death in November 1558 Richardson continued as treasurer clerk and acting treasurer .
#Text=Scottish Reformation
#Text=As acting treasurer , it was probably in this capacity , rather than as " Maister of the Cunze-house " , [ 2 ] that he held the coining irons of the mint at Holyroodhouse .
#Text=In July 1559 the Protestant Lords of the Congregation who occupied Edinburgh seized these , along with great sums of money , claiming that they had done so to stop corruption of the coinage .
#Text=The irons were returned to him according to the terms of the Articles of Leith between the lords and Mary of Guise .

#Text=After the siege of Leith , Richardson sat as a prelate at the Reformation Parliament of 1560 and was listed by Knox among those " that had renunceit Papistrie and oppinlie profest Jesus Chryst with us .
#Text=Moray gave him the revenue arising from wards and marriages and vacant benefices .
#Text=In January 1571 the lease of the mint which he had held since 1566 was renewed for three years , half the profits to be applied to paying off his ˜superexpenses as treasurer .

#Text=According to a contemporary source , John Cunningham of Drumquhassle had been made " half thesaurer , with Mr Robert Ritchartsone that wes thesaurer of befoir " [ 6 ] in July 1570 , but Richardson remained in sole charge until 24 June 1571 , when he was replaced by William , Lord Ruthven .
#Text=He retained control of the mint until March 1573 , his share of the profits amounting to more than £5400 Scots .

#Text=Thereafter he continued to receive money from the mint to redeem the royal jewels that had been pledged to him , further payments being made to his sons after his death , which probably took place between May and November 1578 .
#Text=Family

#Text=Richardson was unmarried but his four children , James , Robert , Stephen , and Janet were legitimated in 1552 ; another child ( Katherine ) may have been born in December 1563 , when Randolph reported to Cecil that Richardson was to do public penance in St Giles for getting a woman with child and Knox was to " mayke the sermonde .
